Key Arguments: The legislation violates democratic and constitutional rights to freedom of speech.
The terms 'misinformation' and 'disinformation' are not clearly defined, allowing for potential misuse by the government.
The premise that the informer is responsible for the actions of the recipient is illogical.
Education and critical thinking should be prioritized over censorship.
No single agency or government can determine absolute truth as societal perceptions evolve.
Silencing dissenting researchers could hinder societal progress.
Notable Quotes: This proposed legislation should be vigorously rejected because it is undemocratic, inherently flawed and founded upon false premises.

The solution to this problem is not to censor all communications, but to a) provide clear, easy-to-find information on the risks of bleach and b) to improve education so that people are better able to make informed decisions about the veracity of the information they read/see.
Societyâ€™s perception of truth is continually evolving, based on growing knowledge and experience.
